threads.com:
The deeper I look inside the body, the more convinced I am God is to be found at the center. Oh, I'm not arguing from some dogmatic religious viewpoint of allfathers and sky judges. Oh, I read the Blind Watchmaker. I smugly believed myself knowledgeable because I knew how an eye could evolve from a simple photoreceptive cell, to an indentation, to a cup, to a basic eye-like shape, gradually filling in the lens and other advancements over time. But then you look inside the cell itself. You look deep at the core of biological life, and it is simply, positively insane.

Synapses. Microtubules. Error correction "machinery". Quantum superposition within neurons. The complexity is mind-boggling. The deeper you go, the more cosmically complex it gets, not less. And you say: 3.5 billion years- a fraction of that until "the first cell"! "3.5 billion years is a long time!" NO! 3.5 billion years is nowhere NEAR enough time for something this vast and indescribable to arise! Oh, I know "mutations aren't random", every iteration builds on its predecessor. Fine! A chimp to a human, fine. A dinosaur to a chicken, fine. A slime to a mammal. No problems! But the insane complexity of the life processes that power these beings cannot be something that self-assembled out of a muck of organic stew a trite, pathetic 3.5 billion years ago. A TRILLION might still be pushing it. To suggest this all arose from carbon and nitrogen bumping into each other is inconceivable. There is more beyond all of this, a great and unknown Something above, behind, within this elegant dance that touches the divine and has life breathed into it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15017998
the authors state there may be methodological errors that they're unaware of. look at them and you'll see a massive sampling bias.

in the first study on humor, their sample size was 65 students from a "variety" of psychology courses who each received extra credit for participating. you should ask how that's possible---how did the authors coordinate with the other psychology classes to allow this? you can effectively treat this as a sampling bias: all students came from a subset of instructors who allowed students to get extra credit for this. furthermore, attempting to gradate these into four quartiles yields each quartile of about 16 students... not statistically significant at all.

in the second study on logical reasoning, the sampling is 45 students from a single psychology course, again awarded extra credit. this is even worse than the first study, both because of lower statistics (each quartile has 11 students) and because the sampling is less diverse.

in the third study on grammar, the sample is 84 students... but the paper doesn't clarify where they're from. i'll be generous and assume it's similar to the first study, where it's a somewhat diverse set of students from a "variety" of psychology courses (i highly doubt it's from different departments, but if it is, that's on the authors for not clarifying what they did...no wonder psychology has a replication crisis kek). again each quartile will have about 21 members, which isn't statistically significant.

the fourth study on logical ability actually has some meat to it. they have higher statistics with 140 students (so each quartile is 35 students, at the cusp of statistical significance). unfortunately, it's still a sampling bias since they all came from a single human development class for extra credit.

(1/2)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15018027
(2/2)

anyone who's taught a class and graded before understands a few key things. firstly, grades are almost always bimodal indicating two distinct populations of students. secondly, in small class sizes, the histograms (if properly binned), usually only have 3 bins of data (these are classes of about 40-50 ime, which is approximately what many of these dunning kruger studies had as samples... so i question their binning for quartiles). thirdly, the population of students who complete extra credit is obviously a subset of the class population (again, a sampling bias).

combining all these observations, the most obvious conclusion i've come to is that the students who complete extra credit assignments are two distinct types of students: the grade grubbing A/B-students and the struggling-to-pass C/D-students. given the low statistics that dunning and kruger found, i'd say they really identified the bimodal nature of students clamoring for extra credit.

the C/D students are the ones who are, quite frankly, stupid (i'm ignoring the ones who are just lazy---remember these are volunteers for extra credit). the A/B students are the ones who understand their own limits (again, restricting focus to extra credit grubbing students).

in sum, dunning kruger effect is mired in poor methodologies. the effects it does tease out are really nothing new, and not what the authors think. they really found a difference between stupid students and bright students (those who care about grades). and their results are NOT representative of more general populations.

>>15017073
it's LINE-1 (LINE is an acronym), and it's specific to less than a fifth of the human genome
it's also extremely strongly down-regulated and not "common", with higher reverse transcription being associated with disorders and the behavior of cancers - i.e. stuff is going wrong if LINE-1 copies are showing up more often in somatic cell genomes

what's more, ORF2 from LINE-1 is very likely LINE-1's own version of a reverse transcriptase - i.e. it still has to bring its own photocopier into the cell factory. there is no evidence i'm aware of that LINE-1's reverse transcriptase-like ORF2 is used by cells to do anything other than copy bits of LINE-1, assuming it is used at all - it's certainly not adding new copies of random mRNA floating around in the cell to the DNA, given the fact LINE-1 is mostly inactive and less than a fifth of the human genome (the rest of the genome is sending mRNA into the cytosol too, y'know)

threads.sub: Infinite sets don't exist or don't have a cardinality
threads.com:
The idea that two infinite sets can have the same cardinality because you can establish a one-to-one correspondence between its members is contradictory since you can also establish a one-to-every-two correspondence, a one-to-every-three, ... , one-to-every-n correspondence. All of which would tell you the two sets have different cardinalities because guess what, since the set isn't finite, you don't know what the last number is, hence you can't really say by mapping one element to every other element you will be able to map all elements or not.

For example, take the set of even natural numbers E and the set of natural numbers N. Set theory books would have you believe that because you can connect the 1st element of E with the 1st element of N, the 2nd of E with the 2nd of N, and so on, that means you established a one-to-one correspondence, and so E and N must have the same cardinality. The problem is that you don't really know if you really able to do that for all elements since you don't know what the last element is. Further, since cardinality is a determined size, an infinite set cannot possible have a cardinality, thus leading to contradictions if you try to compare their non-existence cardinalities as you shall soon see.

Now, instead of mapping the 1st element of E with the 1st element of N, the 2nd of E with the 2nd of N, and so on, map the 1st element of E with the 2nd element of N, the 2nd of E with the 4th of N, the 3rd element of E with the 6th element of N, and so on. By the same reasoning of the "same cardinality via one-to-one correspondence", this should lead you to conclude that E has half the cardinality of N.

Ashkin is generally credited with developing optical tweezers which means stationary trapping of particles, and furthermore the ability to control their motion precisely. He's right. Probability isn't proof. If you can't answer the question WHY a certain cause had a certain effect in a scientific study then you cannot claim to know it.

For example, you could count the sun rising 1,000 times and setting 1,000 times, and then make the claim that the sun will rise 1,001 times. But if you know nothing about the sun, and nothing about the Earth... you will never be able to answer the question why the sun rises.

Once you can answer that question, you leave the world of probability and enter the world of certainty.

Once you figure out the sun is a star, and the earth is a planet, and that the earth is rotating around the sun while also rotating on it's axis. You can make a model and directly understand that the earth's rotation is what makes the sun appear to rise and fall.

threads.com: Putnam problem of the day. Any ideas?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15016618
With C as QP, x as PR, the function is:

C + x / (sqrt(x^2 + c^2)

Then take the derivative and find the roots:

C and -C
or
all points R such that PR = PQ

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15016618
Without loss of generality let
[eqn]
k = \{(x,y,0) \in \mathbb{R}^3 \} \\
P=(0,0,0) \\
Q = (0,0,1)
[/eqn]

We have to maximize
[eqn]\frac{QP+PR}{QR} = \frac{1 + \sqrt{x^2 + y^2}}{\sqrt{x^2 + y^2 + 1}}[/eqn]

By Cauchy-Schwarz applied to the vectors [math](1,1)[/math] and [math](1,\sqrt{x^2 + y^2})[/math] we see that this is always smaller or equal [math]\sqrt{2}[/math] with equality on the circle [math]x^2 + y^2 = 1[/math].

last_replies.com:
>>15016210
>Just because we cannot detect movement and location simultaneously doesn't mean particles exist in all states at once, right?
This is a clunky statement. If you want to talk QM, you need to be more precise. A particle has a wavefunction which is completely deterministic. Only when you act upon the wavefunction with an operator do you get a probability associated to an observable. The commutator algebra for the momentum and position operators implies that no quantum state can simultaneously be both a position and a momentum eigenstate. Therefore, there exists an uncertainty in the position and momentum.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
A video game (for real) has procedurally-based endings. There are six colors, red, orange, yellow, green, blue and purple. Returning any combination of the 6 — including less than 6 — results in a different ending. How do you figure out how many endings there are?

For example:

Red is one ending.

Green is another.

Red + Green is another,

Purple + Yellow + Blue is another

Etc

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15017764
Then it's calculated with combinations without repetition, in the mathematical sense of combination:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combination

These are also binomial coefficients, so you can simply refer to the seventh row of Pascal's triangle (see pic).

Presumably you want at least one color, so you ignore the first 1. Then there are 6 ways to choose 1 color, 15 ways to choose 2 colors, 20 ways to choose 3 colors, 15 ways to choose 4 colors, 6 ways to choose 5 colors, and 1 way to choose 6 colors. You can add these to get the total.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15011700
>>15011675
The distinction you are describing is that between the unarguably non-invasive senses (hearing, seeing) and between the maximally invasive senses (touch, taste) on the other side.

The distinction matters because we are animals. The concept of being felt up by an external actor being cost-free for the actor is antithetical to your prime directive, which is staying alive. There needs to be some cost involved. After munging this concept enough you arrive at the outcome that animals evolve in a way that does not make it advantageous or possible for touch to work as a zero-cost (especially zero entry cost) "pleasure dispenser". Same with taste, but also other reasons (not dying to toxins etc. And a static taste is good for that.).

Smell is the strangest and perhaps the most analog and least digital sense, compared to hearing/vision which 100% are just digital. And no, I don't mean digital as in fingers, of course.

>>15016264
Earth orbital insertion is achieved by using multiple stages; the CSM itself is more constrained. Delta-v requirements from LEO to LLO are lower, but still not zero, meaning that they can't just coast to the Moon If you think about it, the orbital path is a ellipse around Earth; even moving rapidly around the ellipse still means that you stick to the ellipse. And once you get to the Moon, you need to enter lunar orbit, which requires deceleration; otherwise you'd fly by. Lunar Orbital Insertion requires fuel, which has mass, and you are already heavily mass-restricted, so you want an efficient route rather than the quickest theoretical route.

>>15013865
Yes, but the plates have to be gigantic and REALLY close together for it to have any meaningful capacitance. Putting a dielectric material between them can increase the capacitance 1000 fold.

If you want to make a cap, basically put one jar of salt water inside of another jar of salt water. The two reservoirs of water act like the capacitor plates and they're separated by the wall of the inner jar. You'll probably get a capacitance in the nano-farad range, but you can charge it to multi-kilovolt potentials if you charge it with static electricity. Also make sure to use a jar with walls as thin as possible.

For anything better, you'll need to buy some fancy materials.

Regression to the mean occurs even with random noise.

As to why mean values for many traits in humans don't vary that much, that's a different phenomenon that tends to cause successive generations to regress towards the mean of the population they came from.

This is why people have been trying to breed gigantic dogs for plenty of generations but you never get a dog the size of a horse. First, you might have recessive traits that help boost whatever trait you're trying to breed for, and you end up breeding those out of your population.

More importantly, organism are complex dynamical systems. 9 foot long dogs or 9 foot tall people will have all sorts of health problems. There are tons of positive and negative feedback loops designed to stop and organism from changing too dramatically because it will tend to result in something that isn't fit.

No, just start with >>15016954 and eliminate the variables one-by-one. (Fourier-Motzkin Elimination)
First eliminate [math]x_1[/math] to get
[eqn] 3 x_2 + 2 x_3 \geq 0 \\
2 x_2 + 3 x_3 + x_4 \geq 10 \\
x_4 - x_2 \geq 0 \\
x_4 - x_3 \geq 0
[/eqn]
Then eliminate [math]x_2[/math] to get
[eqn] 2 x_3 + 3 x_4 \geq 0 \\
3 x_3 + 3 x_4 \geq 10 \\
x_4 - x_3 \geq 0
[/eqn]
At last eliminate [math]x_3[/math]
[eqn] 5 x_4 \geq 0 \\
6 x_4 \geq 10
[/eqn]
So the optimal solution is [math]x_4 = \frac{5}{3}[/math] going backwards you can also calculate [math]x_1 = x_2 = x_3 = \frac{5}{3}[/math].

last_replies.name: Anonymous

Easiest way to think about possibility:

divide number of expected outcomes by number of possible outcomes.

If the first 10 flips are heads, then the only 2 possibilities remaining are heads/tails for the 11th. So it’s 50/50.

But the probability of getting 11 straight heads with no restriction on the first 10 is extremely small, because the number of possibilities is large, but there is only one expected outcome.
